I desire to say that a Banking Bill had been considered by my predecessor, Sir George Turner, and also by myself, when I was Treasurer ; that a Bill was drafted by the Treasury officials under my direction ; that I consulted the Bank of England in, London and other bankers here; that the Bill was not settled for submission to the Cabinet when I left office ; that the Bill so far as I. had got with it, all the papers connected with it. and also Sir George Turner's notes, were all left in the Treasury when I left office ; that . I never gave any instructions to any officer to burn them, or any other public document, in my life.
Sir WilliamLyne. - Oh !

Sir JohnForrest. - Further, I say that I have consulted Mr. Allen, the Secretary to the Treasury, and he says that Sir William Lyne must be under some great misapprehension, as I never gave any such instruction or made any such suggestion.
Sir WilliamLyne. - I did not say it was Mr. Allen.
Sir JohnForrest. - Mr. Allen goes on to say that the Bill and all the papers, as I left them, are still in the Treasury.
Sir WilliamLyne. - That is not correct.

Mr. THOMASBROWN (Calare) [3.58]. - When the debate has reached a stage at which personal explanations and recriminations are called forth, it is about time that it was ended ; and I do not propose to contribute very much to its length. During the earlier part of the discussion I heard from my side of the House some attempts at congratulating honorable members opposite, though it is true there was a certain strain of irony about the congratulations. However that may be, I do not propose to follow the example then set, because from the attitude which honorable members opposite adopt, and more particularly from the looks they present, I should say they have hardly settled down to the new order . of affairs, or reached the stage at which congratulations are acceptable. But I feel disposed to offer a word of congratulation to the honorable member who is about to quit the position of Prime Minister - the leader of the party with which I have been associated ever since I entered into Commonwealth politics. The people now learn that within the ranks of labour, are to be found gentlemen as capable of discharging the highest functions of administration as any who could be found outside the party, and that the destinies of the Commonwealth are just as safe in their hands as they could possibly be in the hands of others.
Mr. Chanter.- And so is the marriage tie.

Mr. THOMAS BROWN.- Quite so; the marriage tie is just as safe in the hands of the present Government as it could possibly be in the hands of their critics, who have endeavoured to make use ' of this cry about the marriage tie as a means of besmirching and defaming men who are very much better than themselves in this respect. I am glad that an opportunity has been given to the honorable member for Wide Bay, and those associated with him, to disclose what they are able to do ' as administrators ; and' every unbiased man will admit that they have done much to place the public departments on a more stable footing than that on which they found them. Their critics, if they are prepared to give credit where credit is due, must accord that meed of praise to them. I do not wish to lay any special blame on the late Postmaster-General, but the Post and Telegraph Department had drifted into a condition that was making it a by-word amongst the people; and the present PostmasterGeneral has had to adopt some veryunpopular methods to bring about a better state of affairs. He has not been afraid to do so; and I hope that those who succeed him will carry on the good work he has initiated, and, in a short time, re- move amr cause there may be for the complaints and abuse which have been hurled at the Department. Similar observations may be made as to the Defence Department. We have had no proper scheme of defence, and though we have been talking about a citizen soldiery, the forces have never been placed on a practical or satisfactory basis. Apparently the Administration has not had that sympathetic aid it deserves; but the present Minister has made a move in what I think will be regarded as the right direction. Then as to the White Australia legislation, the Fisher Government have signalized themselves by the extent to which they have unearthed and brought to light the various methods by which undesirable immigrants, and also, it may be said, opium, were being introduced. For their work in this connexion the Government have placed the Commonwealth under a debt of gratitude. In regard to the introduction of Asiatic labour, honorable members must adopt two alternatives as an explanation of the work done by the Government, The first is that, when the Chinese learnt that a Labour Government was in control, they thought it a good opportunity to send undesirable immigrants and also opium to Australia. If' that explanation lie not accepted, then the alternative is that the traffic in undesirable labour and opium had been going on more or less largely all the while, and it required a Labour Government to find it out and put a stop to it. Whatever may be the explanation, I think that every believer in the policy of a White Australia - every one desiring to see Australia thickly peopled with white races holding ideals and sympathies akin to his own - will concede that the Government has done good work in both these particulars. I wish to congratulate the Prime Minister on the substantial work he has done in the administration of his Department, and in initiating matters of policy. In the few weeks of the session that remained at his disposal, he lifted the Capital Site question from the ruck into which it had fallen, and remained for years, and enabled it to be satisfactorily dealt with. I trust that those who succeed the present Administration will continue his good work, and carry it to completion. Then, again, the great iron industry received substantial assistance at his hands by the passing of the Manufactures Encouragement Bill, and I trust that before long Australia will be able to produce high class manufactures of metal from her crude ores. Still' another good work done by the present Government was that of giving to the public servants of the Commonwealth the common rights of citizenship enjoyed by the rest of the community - rights that had hitherto been denied them. The Prime Minister showed by his action that he had the courage to strike

*out on new lines. I am sure that the public servants of the Commonwealth are men of intelligence and capacity, and that they will so use their newly acquired privileges that the incoming Government will not dare to attempt to take them from them. In- deed I feel sure, that the States will be compelled to follow in our wake, and that the public servants of the States will soon enjoy these larger measures of citizenship, and use them to the genera] well-being of Australia. In these directions the Government have done good work, which, as a member of the Labour Party, 'I can heartily commend. Then,> again, they met the Parliament with a .policy that is a distinct advance upon and a departure from the policies hitherto submitted. There may be a difference of opinion as to whether it is in the best interests of the Commonwealth, but I am sure those who have considered it for themselves are satisfied that it is not merely new, but distinctly Australian, and fitted to meet the requirements of an Australian community. The incoming Ministry will have to follow closely in the steps of the present Administration." It is significant that those who are opposed to the Government have not dared to attempt to displace them by questioning any of their acts of administration, or the policy which they have submitted to the country. They have adopted other methods knowing full well that for the time being,- at all events, the Labour Government have behind them a large volume of public opinion. They dare not run counter to that opinion, but 'they hope soon to win it back, and to make their footing more secure. I am not here for the special purpose of keeping any particular party in power, but I certainly recognise the importance of effective administration. I want to see good liberal reforms provided for in Commonwealth enactments - reforms which the Commonwealth urgently needs - and I desire to see such measures effectively administered. If, as the result of the fusion of parties, that has taken place, a large section pf the Opposition have been converted from their life-long adherence to Conservative principles, and brought so far under the banner of Liberalism as to be ready to carry out these reforms, I for one shall not complain. I shall certainly do my best to bring about that result ; but I question very much whether that is the object lying behind the movement. I am fearful that it is intended not to bring about liberal reforms, not to secure the passing of legislation thatwill benefit the whole community, and will not bend to special interests and privileges, but to keep up those special privileges, and to bend the powers of legislation and of administration, as they have been bent in the past. For that reason, I sincerely regret that the Fisher Administration is to give place to a Ministry representing the fusion Of parties. However, by their acts . they must be judged, and I shall await .with interest a statement of the work they propose to do. I see before me a combination of parties and interests that hitherto have been vitally antagonistic. We have before us the extreme Conservatives on the free-trade side sitting with the' Liberal or "good as a Labour man." We have, too, the extreme Con- servative on the protectionist side sitting with the Liberal or " good as a Labour man." Then, again, we have still another party consisting of honorable members who, so far as I am aware, have never professed any sympathy with democratic aspirations or legislation. That party held the balance of power, when the Tariff was under consideration, and exercised it in the interests of the wealthy section of the community. > Whenever they were called upon to vote for an item which meant high protection, and at the same time would yield much revenue, they voted with the protectionists to carry it into law. On the other hand, if, by voting with the free-trade section, they could secure the passing of a large revenue producing item, and defeat the protectionists, they were quite prepared to do so. The result is that the present Tariff is one of the highest revenue producing Tariffs, and, therefore, is incompatible with any degree of protection or free-trade. Those who so devised it took good care that the burdens of its revenue-producing items were placed, not upon the shoulders of the particular section of the community that they represented, not upon the shoulders of those best able to bear taxation, but upon the shoulders of the starving men and women, the workers of the Commonwealth. I fear that that policy will be repeated- in connexion with this fusion, and that, instead of getting liberal reforms, as some honorable members on the other side hope, from the present combination, they will find themselves, as in the case of -the Tariff, the tools of that extremely conservative Opposition Corner; who are out to look after the interests of their own particular section, of' the community, as no doubt they are entitled to do. If they can use the democrats on that side of the House to further their interests, so much the worse for those democrats. I am very glad that we have reached a stage which I regard as an epoch-making one in the history of the Commonwealth and of Commonwealth politics. Our lines are now ' diverging. In the division which was recently taken, and in the divisions to be taken, there will be found on the one side of the House those who are pledged up to the hilt to the democracy of Australia, those who have in their life-work outside and inside the House done something substantial for the democracy, and on the other will be found from this time forward those who are opposed to generally beneficial reforms, and strive by legislation and administration to further the interests of the specially wealthy classes of the community. We have reached a position where we can have a straight-out fight, and the electors will not in the future, as in the past, be hoodwinked by side issues such as free-trade and protection, or the claims of candidates to be "as-good-as; Labour-men." There will be the two issues presented to them of radical democracy and old-time Conservatism, and they will' be able to make, their choice. If they are wise in their day and generation they will not spend forty years wandering in the wilderness of inconclusive and. unsatisfactory legislation and administration, but will strike straight out for the land of promise. The sooner they make up their minds to attain that object, the sooner they will get there, and the democrats on this side of the House will do their level best to get them there, and keep them there. I wish to commend the Prime Minister, who is about to retire from office, for the good work he has done,- not only in the administration of the functions of government, but in keeping the party free in years gone by from any alliance, combination, or fusion that would submerge its identity, and prevent it from being the live fighting factor that it has been. In the years to come there will not be so much danger on that score as there was in years goneby. We have heard recently about the negotiations that took place here for an alliance or combination of the Labour Party with others, and the House probably realizes that that attempt, about which there has been so much bitter contention to-day, was not the first of its kind. There had been previous moves in that direction, and it took sturdy, strong men in the Labour movement to keep it free from those entanglements. It has been kept free, and to-day it goes forward on a mew line of progress. I think that in bringing that about those who have been engaged in this great struggle have realized the expectations of those who sent them here. We have now, as we had before, two parties in the House, but before we had them so confused by other issues that the electors were unable to distinguish them. To-day the electors can distinguish them.They find that under the compelling force of the growing labour movementthosewhose opinions yesterday seemed to be as far apart as the poles, and who have called each other hard and bitter names, are to-day ranged under one banner and under one leader. That banner is antilabour, and that leader is against the labour movement, however much he may deny it.

Mr. MAUGER(Maribyrnong) [4.41].- I shall endeavour to keep as free as possible from the personalities that have so much degraded this debate, and to confine myself to facts. I am extremely sorry that the honorable member for Hume has left the Chamber, because I intended to direct his attention to the fact that he was not always so anxious about the future of the protective policy and the Protectionist Party as he appears to be at present.I shall show that he was prepared to enter into an alliance with a party containing a large number of free-tmders - not freetraders who had agreed to a common platform and a common policy, but free-traders who claimed freedom of action on Tariff matters.
Dr. Maloney.- Are they on this side?

Mr. MAUGER.-They were, and are now. I shall prove from documentary evidence that theywere given freedom of action, not at a time when the Tariff had been settled, as the last speaker said, on the highest basis yet reached, but when there was in force a Tariff which was crippling the industries of Victoria. What was the honorable member for Hume's anxiety then ? He was prepared to enter into an alliance-
Mr. Storrer.- He was in the same party, as the honorable member then.
Mr. MAUGER.- It is a pity he is not in the same party now. It would be much better for him.
Mr. Spence.- He is too straightfor that.

Mr. MAUGER.- Ithinkhis straightness, and his crookedness also, are recognised. He was prepared to enter into an alliance that provided that " the free-trade members of the Labour Party shall have perfect freedom of action to vote for or against any proposed reduction or increase of duty." The honorable member for Hume now objects to the' position taken up by the right honorable member for East Sydney. He claims that protection is in imminent danger at a time when the highest Tariff that.has ever been placed upon the statute-book of Australia is the law of the land, and yet, long before this Tariff was even inaugurated, he was prepared to ally himself with the free-traders in 'the Labour Party, and to give them freedom to vote just as they liked upon any items submitted, in order that he might get into office.
Mr. Hutchison.-Exactly, because he knew that the Tariff would be all right.

Mr. MAUGER.- We knew that our Tariff would be all right. But we also knew that there were free-traders in the Labour Party who were prepared to make it all wrong. My honorable friend knows that. Yet the honorable member for Hume was prepared to enter into a compact with them. Here is a statement made by the honorable member for South Sydney, then leader of the Labour Party, as to the agreement entered into. Each member was to- decide for himself how far the particular circumstances prove necessity or the extent to which the proposal should be carried.

The honorable member for Hume had absolutely no objection to enter into an alliance with honorable members opposite on terms giving the free-traders of that party a free hand upon the Tariff, whenmany of the industries of Victoria were positively being snuffed out in consequence of the duties in existence.
Mr. Storrer.- The Labour Party is not a free-tradeparty.
Mr. MAUGER.- There are five freetraders in the present Ministry.
Mr. Storrer.- Who are they?
Mr. MAUGER.-There are the Prime Minister-
Mr. Hutchison.- He is not a freetrader.
Mr. Fisher.- I supported the Kingston Tariff. I never stood as a tariffite at any time. I always stood as a Labourite.
Mr. MAUGER.- My honorable friend is evading the question. Did he enter this Parliament as a free-trade labour man?
Mr. Fisher.- No.
Mr. MAUGER.-Then how did he enter Parliament in regard to the fiscal question?
Mr. Bamford.- Let the honorable member look up the Prime Minister's votes upon axe-handles, and find out.
Mr. MAUGER.-Oh, yes; when it was a matter of axe-handles or bananas, there were several ofthe free-traders opposite who gave protectionist votes.
Mr. HumeCook. - The Prime Minister gave more free-trade than protectionist votes in the first Parliament. We always looked upon him as oneof the free-traders.
Mr. JosephCook. - Hear, hear !
The DEPUTY SPEAKER.- I must ask honorable members to cease theseinterjections.
Mr. MAUGER.- I say again that the Prime Minister entered this Parliament as a free-trader. I say, also, that the PostmasterGeneral is a free-trader. The Minister of Defence is a free-trader.
Mr. Fisher. - I have answered the hon orable member, yet he continues to say the same thing. How can one deal with a man of that kind ?
Mr. MAUGER.-The honorable gentleman has not answered me.
Mr. Fisher.- Let the honorable member ask his leader.
Mr. MAUGER.-A labour man is " neither fish, nor flesh, nor good red herring." in regard to the Tariff.
Mr. McDougall. - Is the party to which the honorable member now belongs in favour of the new protection?

Mr. MAUGER.- What was the use of talking about the principle of the new protection until we had established the old protection ? Many of us on this side of the House were advocates of the application of the new protection long before some of the members of the Labour Party came into the political arena.
Mr. McDougall.- Does the honorable member expect to get the new protection established by the votes of those on his own side of the House?
Mr. MAUGER.-We are quite as likely to get it from this side of the House as from the Labour Party, who, as I said before, are "neither fish, nor flesh, nor good red herring " on the fiscal issue.
Dr. Maloney.- The honorable member has only mentioned three members of the present Government who he says are freetraders. He said there were five. Who are the others?
Mr. MAUGER.-I will mention the five. First, the Prime Minister says that he is neither protectionist nor free-trader.
Mr. Fisher.- I shall take no further notice of the honorable member's statement.

Mr. MAUGER.-I know that the Prime Minister voted against us nine times out of ten on the first Tariff. I know also that the first Tariff was rendered largely inoperative from my point of view owing to free-trade reductions.At that time, the new protection was not on the platform of the Labour Party. They adopted it after they were forced by sheer weight of public opinion, and when they began to recognise the importance of the fiscal question. But no one can deny that it was absolutely essential to establish protective duties of Customs before the principle of new protection could be applied.
Mr. Hall.- Who first brought the new protection policy forward?
Mr. MAUGER.- The Anti-Sweating League and the Protectionist Society of Victoria advocated the principle long before my honorable friend ever dreamed of entering the Federal Parliament.
Mr. Hall.- When?
Mr. Deakin.- In the early nineties.
Mr. MAUGER.- It was advocated when the Bill for the Federation of Australia was under discussion.
Mr. McDougall.- Is Mr. Walpole a member of the Anti-Sweating League?

Mr. MAUGER.-I know nothing about Mr. Walpole. The honorable member seems to know a good deal about him. My point is that the honorable member for Hume cannot logically or consistently find fault with a party such as this, on the lines on which it is organized, in view of the fact that he was prepared to receive free-traders into his party, and to give them an absolutely free hand on the Tariff, although he knew that at that time Tariff reform was absolutely essential, whatever may be the position at the present time. Now I come to another point.
Mr. Tudor.- The honorable member is absolutely wrong. His present party opposed protection, and he knows it.

Mr. MAUGER.-The very term "new protection" was coined in my office. The honorable member for Yarra ought to know that. But he is a mere pigmy - a baby in politics. Until he came out as a candidate for Yarra, he knew nothing about the question. I venture to say that he never heard the term newprotection until he came to Australia. The principle was advocated in this country before he came here.
Mr. Tudor.- I was born in the country.
Mr. Batchelor.- The honorable member simply means that the phrase was coined in his office.
Mr. Tudor.- The honorable member for Bourke got up in his place and opposed the new protection principle.

Mr. MAUGER.- Both the phrase and the principle for which it stands were formulated there. I shall be very happy to show the Minister of Trade and Customs a document which sets out a resolution carried at a joint conference of the Protectionist Association and the Trades Hall Council, in which the general principle was laid down.
Mr. Tudor.-When?

Mr. MAUGER.- During the time when the first Tariff was being introduced. That resolution laid down the principle that before Wages Boards or Arbitration Courts - which are the instruments of what is known as the new protection - can be applied, the old protection must be secure. That resolution, as I say, was signed by representatives of the Trades Hall Council and of the Protectionist Association. I repeat that the phrase was coined in my office, it was advocated by the Age, and worked out as a practical scheme, long before my honorable friend dreamt of entering the political arena or took a part in political matters.
Mr. Batchelor.- The honorable member refers only to the phrase.
Mr. MAUGER.-And also to the principle.
Mr. Batchelor.- No.
Mr. MAUGER.- In 1894, in conjunction with the present leader of the Opposition, we were working at the establishment of the first Wages Boards ever introduced into Australia.
Dr. Maloney.- That is right.
Mr. MAUGER.- My honorable friend, the member for Melbourne knows that that is so. He was working with us.
Mr. Hall.- Were the Wages Boards to apply only to the protected industries ?
Mr. MAUGER.-Evidently the honorable member does not know how many Wages Boards there are in this State now.
Mr. Batchelor.-That had nothing to do with protection.
Mr. MAUGER.- It had everything to do with protection. The principle was that these Boards should be applied to all protected trades.
Dr. Maloney.- That was the only thing that made protection decent.
Mr. Tudor.- And it was aprinciple that honorable members opposite opposed.

Mr. MAUGER.- I am speaking within the knowledge of men who have been associated with me foryears, and I say again that we have consistently advocated the application of the principle of the new protection, and did so long before the Labour Partyassociated themselves with it. I say also that that principle is just as safe in our hands as in the hands of the Labour Party. The country knows that, and will confirm what we have done.
Mr. Tudor.- We hope that the country will have a chance of expressing its opinion.

Mr. MAUGER.- The country will have a chance in good time. If my honorable friend consulted the best interests of the country rather than what he considers to be the chance of snatching a party victory, he would not advocate a dissolution at the present time.I notice that the Prime Minister, on two occasions, has repeated, and that two leading members opposite have said, that a dissolution should come now. A dissolution of this Parliament should come when the business of this Parliament is completed. It would be unjustifiable to cause the expense of an election in two succeeding years. It would be unwarranted to appeal to the country when there is in this Parliament a party which is prepared to carry on the business of the country. Not that I fear a dissolution, but I say that the conduct of the business which this Parliament has to do is more important than a dissolution. I am sorry that the honorable member for Hume is not present, because I wish now to allude to a statement he made in reference to an attempted alliance or coalition between the Labour Party and a section of the late Deakin Government.
Mr. McWilliams.- What is the good of it all?
Mr. KingO'Malley. - The honorable member knows that the honorable member for Hume in speaking was excited.

Mr. MAUGER.- Unfortunately, statements made in excited, moments are used on the public platform, falsified, exaggerated, and turned and twisted, very often in such a way as to appear to be exactly the opposite to what they are. The facts are that when the Post Office crisis arose there was at the back of it some of the very worst forces of Australia. That crisis was brought about because I determined that a public utility should not be made use of for gambling or immoral purposes.
Mr. Tudor.- Is that why the honorable gentleman dropped the Telegraph Bill?

Mr. MAUGER.- That is another of the honorable member's innuendoes. I never brought forward a Telegraph Bill, and never dropped one. The honorable member is always making innuendoes carrying inferences which he knows to be untrue. I repeat that I know nothing whatever about a Telegraph Bill, and never dropped one. I am prepared to admit that the honorable member for Yarra backed up my action ; but I do say that my attempts to keep that public utility free from the operations of those engaged in gambling and immoral practices led to my being treated in a way that was simply brutish, and almost unbeatable, and that the Post Office crisis was largely brought about through my action in regard to those particular matters.
Mr. McWilliams.-And some of the men who supported the honorable gentleman most strongly were amongst those who at the time sat directly opposite to him.
Mr. MAUGER.- Let me say, also, that amongst those who supported me most strongly was the present Prime Minister.
Mr. Hutchison.- And the honorable gentleman is now associated with some of those who opposedhim.

Mr. MAUGER.- Some of the mostbitter opposition came from the man whowas responsible for the crisis. I say that advisedly, and am prepared to prove it. At that time the then Prime Minister said that the state of his health, and other circumstances, demanded that he should retire, and he handed over to Sir William Lyne authority to attempt to effect an alliance between the Labour Party and the then. Liberal Party. If there is now an alliance which my honorable friends opposite do not like, and which they believe will retard progress - though I do not think it will, for a moment - they and they alone are responsible forit, because of their isolation, their selfishness, and their machine politics.
Mr. KingO'Malley. - The honorable gentleman should not get excited.
Mr. Mathews.- Is their machine politics any worse than dictation by the Age newspaper ?

Mr. MAUGER.- I will ask the honorable member for Darwin whether I am not right when I say that there is not a single member of the Labour Party who is not first responsible to the labour leagues, and who must not first be indorsed by them before he can go to his constituency.
Mr. Spence.- That is not correct.
Mr. KingO'Malley.-They all have to be selected.
Dr. Maloney.- I have been selected, and I am proud of it.
Mr. Tudor.- Who selects the honorable member's crowd?
Mr. MAUGER.-No one selects me.
Mr. Mathews.- They have to be selected by the Age.
Mr. MAUGER.- The Age may support or oppose me, but it does not attempt to say that I must sign a pledge to submit myself to the Age before I can go to my constituency.
Mr. McDougall.- Is not Joshua, the grogmaker, the political boss of the honorable member's party ?

Mr. MAUGER.- I know nothing about Joshua or Moses either. I am discussing now the methods of the Labour Party. I said at a meeting in my constituency, and I repeat the statement to-day, that there is not a single member of the present Labour Ministry or Labour Party who is not first responsible to an irresponsible labour league.
Mr. Batchelor.- What does the honorable gentleman mean by "first responsible."
Mr. MAUGER. - A member of the party must first be selected by a labour league.
Mr.Batchelor. - Exactly.

Mr. MAUGER.- The league may be comprised of 100 members, and there are many that have nothing like that membership, and it can compel the labour candidate to stand down, and he can never reach his constituency.
Mr.Batchelor. - That is not true. It is utterly ridiculous.
Mr. MAUGER.-It is true in Victoria, and true in New South Wales.
Mr.Mathews. - There is nothing to be ashamed of in it in Victoria.
Mr. MAUGER.-There is nothing to be ashamed of in it, if an honorable member is prepared to be a machine politician, and not a democrat.
Mr.Mathews. - I would rather be a machine politician than be subject to the Age newspaper, as the honorable member is.
Mr.Tudor. - Did not the honorable member have to stand down once?

Mr. MAUGER.-No ; I was never allied to theLabour Party as it is at present constituted. When I was associated with the labour leagues with Lormer and others there was in existence what was called the Progressive Liberal League; which was not allied to the labour unions.
Mr.Tudor. - When was this?
Mr. MAUGER.-Before the honorable member appeared in the political arena. He is merely repeating what he heard. He personally knows nothing aboutit.
Mr.Tudor.- I do.

Mr. MAUGER.- The honorable member ought to know that the present political labour machine came into force about the time when the honorable member for Bourke was asked to sign the labour pledge, and when the honorable member for Richmond, in the State Parliament, refused to sign the labour pledge. He must know that that is what separated the honorable member for Richmond from the Labour Party in Victoria. I was allied with the Labour Party, just as the honorable member for Parramatta was, at a time when there was no pledge. I was not pledged to the party, but I received their support, and should be receiving their support to-day if they were anything like loyal to people who made some sacrifices for them. I never signed any pledge.
Mr.Tudor. - Was not the honorable member asked to stand down for East
Bourke Boroughs, and did not McKenzie and Warde get the selection in 1892 ?
Mr. MAUGER.- There was no pledge in existence at the time.
Mr.Tudor. - Did the honorable member nominate for East Bourke Boroughs in 1892 ?

Mr. MAUGER.-I did; but I never signed the labour pledge. I never signed any pledge that I would not stand again if I was not selected. That is the matter with whichI quarrel. As the honorable member for Ballarat stated at the Town Hall the other night, we have no objection to selection by the party. Every party must make selections. Every party must decide what candidates it will support ; but outside the Political Labour Party no party calling itself a democratic party says " You must first come to us. We have the right to decide whether you shall go to the constituency." The honorable member for Yarra knows that he cannot stand for a constituency until he is selected. Until he is selected, no member of the Labour Party can go to the electors.
Dr.Maloney. - As a labour candidate.
Mr. MAUGER.-That is so.
Mr.Tudor. - I think they will select me. I have run straight.
Mr. MAUGER.-That is another dirty innuendo. The honorable member is not the only member who has run straight.
Mr.Tudor. - The honorable member does not appear to like it.

Mr. MAUGER.- I have no objection to it, but I will tell the honorable member what I do like. I like straightforward statements. I do not believe in dirty inferences. No man can say that I have not run straight throughout my political career. I have run as straight as has the honorable member who makes the dirty insinuations. The honorable member for Yarra knows verywell that what I am stating is correct. He says that he will obtain the selection of the labour league. I hope that he will. But he admits there is a possibility that he may not.
Mr.Tudor. - Hear, hear !

Mr. MAUGER.-Then I ask, "To whom is he first responsible - to the league or to his constituency?" I shall say no more at the present juncture, but I wished to make clear these one or two points in connexion with the matter which has been discussed.
Mr. CHANTER(Riverina) [4.46].- I regret that the leader of the Opposition has made no reply to the statement read by the honorable member for Hume.
Mr.Deakin. - I was making a personal explanation at the time, and thuswas prevented from doing so.

Mr. CHANTER.- When certain nego tiations were taking place for the combination that has now been effected, the honorable member for Ballarat stated that the Free-trade Party had agreed not to interfere with the presentTariff in any shape or form, except so far as the correction of anomalies was concerned. Now the right honorable member for East Sydney has published to the world a declaration that he made no such agreement with the honorable member. He asserts that he agreed not" to interfere with the Tariff as it stood, but that he reserved to himself and the whole of his Free-trade Party a free hand in regard to the correction of anomalies.
Mr.Deakin. - You will find the explanation published in the newspapers tomorrow morning. It has been given to the press.

Mr. CHANTER.-I think that the honorable member will find before long that he has associated himself with persons with whom it is necessary that all agreements should be put into writing,so that they may be produced when occasion arises.
Mr.Mathews. - The honorable member wants them to give a pledge?
Mr. CHANTER.-Of course.

Mr.Deakin. - This is what I read: " No interference with the protectionist policy of the present Customs Tariff in rectifying anomalies " ; and the reference of the right honorable member for East Sydney relates to the word " anomalies." He claims the right to exercise his judgment as to whether an anomaly is an alleged or a real one.

Mr. CHANTER.-The right honorable member for East Sydney, in his published statement, declares that at the meeting of the two parties, he made it abundantly clear that the membersof his party were to have a perfectly free hand in dealing with all matters of Tariff concern which did not involve an interference with the Tariff as it stands to-day. Where it is shown that, in the interests of Australian industries, it is absolutely necessary to correct anomalies, he has proclaimed to the world that he reserves to himself and his party a perfectly free hand. If that is an alliancewhich is satisfactory to honest protectionists I' am at a loss to understand it.

Mr. J.H. CATTS (Cook) [4.50].- During his speech this afternoon the honorable member for Dalley referred to my connexion with an Orange lodge. I wish therefore to make one or two remarks in the calmest possible way, and without the introduction of the slightest feeling. Prior to the last election I was for some ten or twelve years a member of an Orange lodge. I joined that organization in my teens, when it was a religious, and not a political, body. When I was selected as a labour candidate prior to the Federal elections I was invited by the Orange lodges in my constituency to submit my name to them for selection. I refused to do so. They selected the chairman of the Importers' Association of Sydney, Mr. Hindle. He was my opponent, and they placed upon him the official seal of the organization. The honorable member for Dalley stated that I sought the support of the Orange lodges.
Mr.Wilks. - Did not the honorable member go round to those lodges asking for votes?

Mr. J.H. CATTS.- I did not. I do not charge the honorable member with having made a statement which he knows to be untrue, but I do say that he has either been misinformed or has misunderstood his informant. At the opening meeting of my campaign, in. the Newtown Town Hall, I was asked whether I would accept support from Orangemen, and I replied that I would accept support from any persons who chose to extend it to me upon the labour platform, irrespective of whether they were Orangemen or Roman Catholics. I wish to tell the honorable member for Dalley that I am prepared to deposit £5 with any honorable member whom he may choose to nominate, conditionally that he lodges a similar amount; and if it can be shown that I solicited support from any Orange organization after my announcement or selection as a Federal labour candidate, I am prepared to forfeit the money to any hospital in New South Wales, the honorable member to do likewise if proved wrong. I regret to say that, although there were ministers of the Gospel who entered Orange lodges, knelt down, and placed their hands upon the open Bible, and declared that they would not see a brother misrepresented, those very ministers subsequently went round my electorate misrepresenting me. Not only that, but members of the Orange institution have endeavoured to induce those of an opposite persuasion not to record their votes in my favour on the ground that I belonged to the same institution as themselves. I know that I have received votes from democratic Orangemen., as well as from other democratic parties. No organization could prevent some men from voting for labour candidates. It is that fact which largely influenced the Orange organization in its recent determination to make a show for democracy as against the hide-bound conservatism which it had previously supported. I hope that the institution will support democratic principles, although 1 beg leave to doubt it. The honorable member for Dalley also referred to the alleged tyranny of the Labour League. I desire to mention a little bit of tyranny on the part of some of the Orange lodges. During the State elections which followed the Federal elections the then Premier, of New South' Wales, Sir J. H. Carruthers, introduced the Tariff issue. In my electorate his candidate running for the Camperdown State seat had a placard about 10 feet by 10 feet showing a large loaf and a little loaf, and calling upon the electors in that part of my constituency to vote against the Labour candidate because of some alleged sins I had committed federally in connexion with the Tariff. I received letters from the Labour leagues, and also from the candidate, asking me if I was going to cowardly stand by and see him maligned on account of votes I had given in the Federal Parliament, and I replied " No." I went from this House to place myself alongside that man on the platform, and the result was that we administered an overwhelming defeat to those opposed to our party. It happened that in this State election the gentleman who was .selected as the anti-Labour candidate, Mr.Clegg, had opposed me most bitterly at the Federal election. He was, and is, a member of the Orange lodge, and was the selected Orange candidate in the State fight for the Camperdown seat, when I took the platform for the Labour candidate. I did not inquire what denomination the latter belonged to. All I wanted to know was that he held the same political faith as I did. I left him to profess his religion at whatever shrine he thought best, as a matter concerning his own conscience only. When that State election was finished the Orange lodge in Camperdown laid a charge against me of having spoken against the selected representative of the Orange institution. While I was sitting in this Chamber I received letters stating that a charge had been laid against me, and calling.upon me to attend to answer it. I replied, stating that I could not leave my place in Parliament to attend a committee meeting of the Orange lodge. They wanted me to attend on a Thursday night. That would have meant losing a whole week. I asked the lodge if they would fix the meeting foi Saturday night. They refused to accede to my request. In my absence they heard the charge against me, and found that I had spoken at Camperdown in support oi a. Labour candidate against a selected Orange candidate, and I was forthwith expelled from the Orange institution. 1 have the whole of the correspondence, and, if necessary, can produce it. The honorable member for Dalley spoke of the tyranny of Labour leagues. If any one asks me whether I am prepared to accept that kind of tyranny and indorse it - I do not care whether it is known by the name of religion or not - I cannot indorse it. It is a monstrous thing that an attempt should be made in this free country to prevent a representative of the people in the National Parliament' from defending his actions, his policy, and his party on the public platform. I, for one, will not tolerate it from any section of the community whatever.
Mr. Mcdougall.- Was the honorable member expelled from an Orange lodge because he voted for a Labour candidate?
Mr. Wilks.- Let those who treated the honorable member in that way answer him. He has forgotten a lot. This is only a one-sided statement.

Mr. J.H. CATTS.- If there is anything omitted or forgotten I would be glad if the honorable member would remind me by interjection or speech. The honorable member spoke with me on the subject, as also did several of the high officials in the Grand >Lodge. They asked me if I would submit an appeal to the Grand Lodge against the decision of the branch lodge. The honorable member said he thought that if I liked to appeal I would be reinstated.
Mr. Wilks.- From the honorable member's statement I thought that he had been badly treated.

Mr. J.H. CATTS.- Exactly. Some leading members of the Orange institution said the same thing, and invited me to appeal, and I replied that I would not appeal, as I did not want to belong to them any longer. Since my election to a representative position I have acknowledged neither one party nor the other. I was elected on the Labour platform, and it is my political duty to give effect to it. I know no creeds either on one side or the other. I claim for myself the right to worship where I choose, and I am prepared to allow that liberty to any one who holds different views. I feel no bitterness towards any man because he does not belong to the same church as I do, and I hope that he cherishes no such feeling against me.
Mr. Wilks.- The honorable member is not asked to do so by the Orange institution.
Mr. J.H. CATTS. -No, I was not when I joined the institution, but unfortunately it includes a number of men whom one cannot please unless he is bitter against other men.
Mr. Wilks.- The honorable member is not asked to do what he is stating.

Mr. J.H. CATTS.- It is not what one is asked to do, but what is actually done. From the honorable member's statement it might have appeared that I wished to introduce the question of one man's religion against another man's into the Labour movement. That I have always refused to do. I do not seek support on any other than political or ethical grounds. If a man is suffering in any way he should have a remedy, and should not be pitted against another man because of his religion.
Mr. Wilks.- The honorable member knows by his own experience that it is not done.

Mr. J.H. CATTS.- I know that the Chairman of the Importers' Association of New South Wales was selected on behalf of the Reid-Cook Party as a candidate against me. I also know that he had the official indorsement of the Orange institution, and that he is not regarded as a Democrat. Iknow that he sought support from working men, and I know that working men in my constituency were asked, to vote against Labour proposals, against the nationalization of monopolies and other things which if nationalized would confer a benefit upon them - not on the ground that the nationalization of monopolies was a good thing or a bad thing, but on the ground that one man went to one church and another man went to another church. I have refused to associate these questions with the remedies for the troubles under which working men are suffering. I intend to continue to pursue that course. Unfounded statements have been made as to church influences, sporting influences, gambling influences, and vested interests of various kinds. I for one will withstand any influence of this description, whether it comes from one section or from another. I am endeavouring to do justice to the masses, no matter what side they belong to, and to do my best to give effect to the policy I was sent here to carry out- to place the Labour platform on the statute-book of Australia.

Mr. TUDOR(Yarra- Minister of Trade and Customs) [5.3]. - It was not my intention to speak in this debate; in fact, I understood when we met this morning that in all probability we would adjourn in. about five minutes, but I desire to reply to some remarks made by the honorable member for Maribyrnong, criticising the method of selection by a party which he says he has never belonged to. Apparently, persons who are outside an organization profess to know more about it than those who are inside it. Any person in the community can join the Labour organization, and after the expiration of three months in some States and of a longer period in other States - it is just according to the rules of the various States - he can vote in the selection of all candidates. That is the method of selection in our party. Now, what is the method of selection in the party led by the leader of the Opposition ? Let me go back to the last election, when there was a selection for the neighbouring constituency of Batman, and its present representative decided to stand for election. A deputation from the first meeting came up and waited upon the honorable member for Bourke in his room, and were told that the candidate, Mr. Coon, would have to sign a pledge that he would stand down if he was not selected by them - an organization of two or three persons.
Mr. HumeCook. - That is absolutely incorrect.

Mr. TUDOR.-And, what is more, I have seen a letter in the honorable member's handwriting which I do not think he will deny, to Mr. Hodges, who proposed to stand as a candidate for Mernda, and in which it is stated that unless he agreed in writing to abide by the selection of the Ministry or the committee that was formed, he would have to stand down. Does the honorable member deny that?
Mr. HumeCook. - Let the honorable member bring the letter and we will see.

Mr. TUDOR.- The honorable member knows that he cannot deny that, and I can bring men who were present at the deputation which waited on him in connexion with the selection of a Liberal candidate for' Batman. The honorable member for Maribyrnong talked about persons having the audacity to stand up here and speak about the method of selection by the Labour organization, where every member can take part in the work. What about the method of selection by two or three persons?
Mr. Mauger.- I offered no objection to the selection. That is not the point.
Mr. TUDOR.-That is the objection which the honorable member and those of his party have all along urged against the labour organization.
Mr. HumeCook. - I have a press copy of the letter to which the honorable member has referred.

Mr. TUDOR.-The press copy of the letter sent to Mr. Hodges, who proposed to stand for Mernda, and afterwards stood for Kooyong? I am not sure that the original is not in my possession. It is useful to keep letters like that, which show that the candidates of the Liberal Party were selected by a committee of two or three which was self-appointed, no one having an opportunity to criticise the manner in which its duties were performed.
Mr. Mauger.- There is no comparison between the two methods.
Mr. TUDOR.-The honorable member is right ; there is no comparison.
Mr. Mauger.- We do not ask candidates to pledge themselves.

Mr. TUDOR.-I think that the honorable member for Ballarat was chairman of the committee. No one knows whether it was a committee of two or three, or of more. At any rate, no outsider had any " say " in the appointment of its members. The Labour organization requires intending candidates to submit their names for selection. A man who is not selected cannot carry the labour flag.
Mr. Deakin.- The organization says that he :never shall.
Mr. Batchelor.- No; the decision is for one election only.

Mr. TUDOR.-Honorable members of the Liberal Party also require its candidates to submit themselves for selection. The honorable member for Batman knows this to be correct. I saw him walking up and down outside this building while his committee were inside deliberating as to his selection, and the honorable member for Bourke said on that occasion, "We do not know yet. Mr. Higgins is a member of our party. and you will not be allowed to oppose him." The deputation from the honorable member was told that he could not even submit himself as a Liberal candidate for selection unless Mr. Higgins was made a Justice of the High Court, it being the wish of the Ministry of the day that Mr. Higgins should not be opposed. The honorable member for Batman had to Sen a promise that he would not stand for the position, in order to become eligible for selection by the committee.
Mr. Batchelor.- So he signed a pledge !
Mr. TUDOR.- Yes, that is so, according to the statements of those who were present at the meeting.
Mr. Mauger.- Nothing of the kind.
Mr. TUDOR.- Mr. Hodgeshad to do so.
Mr. Mauger.- Mr. Hodges did nothing of the kind.

Mr. TUDOR.- The honorable member for Batman will not deny that he signed a labour pledge. I know that he did so on more than one occasion. He ran for a seat in the Collingwood Council without being selected to represent labour, and did not get in ; but when he put up next time, as a pledged labour man, he got in. He signed to run as a labour candidate for Batman, but, at that time,. the Labour Party did not take the action which the honorable member thought it should take. I should not have risen, however, had it not been for the statements of the honorable member for Maribyrnong regarding the new protection. Incidentally I have shown that these "pure merinoes," who say that they will not have anything to do with selection as it is practised by the. Labour organization, compel the candidates of their party to submit themselves for selection by committees not one-tenth as large as those of the Labour Party.
Mr. Mauger.- We have urged no objection to the system of selecting candidates. .
Mr. HumeCook. - Has a Ministry no right to say who shall put up as its supporters ?
Mr. TUDOR.-Only under a Tammany organization. The honorable member has not yet replied to the challenge which appeared in the Herald the other night.
Mr. HumeCook. - I have replied, but my letter has not been published.
Mr. TUDOR.-The Tammany organization is a self-appointed committee like this of the Liberal Party, with a " boss," who runs things as he pleases.
Mr. KingO'Malley. - The "boss" of Tammany is picked by the outside councils.

Mr. TUDOR.-But outsiders have no " say " in the matter. The honorable member for Maribyrnong said that these things happened before I came to Australia, forgetting, or perhaps not knowing, that I was born here. I may have been absent in America or England when he stood as a Labour candidate under the organization which preceded the present Labour organization.
Mr. Mauger.- I was not then asked for a pledge of any description.

Mr. TUDOR.-Those who determined that a pledge must be required of Labour candidates built a lot better than they knew, as the events of the last few days have shown. Can the honorable member say that he has remained true to his election pledges, whilst sitting beside the honorable member for Flinders? One of them must lave broken his election pledges, unless the honorable member for Flinders has come along marvellously.
Mr. Mauger.- I hope that he has.

Mr. TUDOR.-So do I ; but the honorable member does not believe that he has. Can they remain true to their pledges and sit side by side, banded together solelyto turn the Labour Party out of office? Those who framed the Labour organization did better work than they anticipated when they decided that written pledges should be required from candidates on the platform which they should support if they were elected, and that meetings of the party should decide what action should be taken by it on any plank of the platform. The honorable member for Maribyrnong was elected as a protectionist, and so was the honorable member for Grampians. Both were chosen by the same newspaper.
Mr. Mauger.- I was not chosen by the newspaper.

Mr. TUDOR.-The honorable member was on the ticket of a newspaper as a pro tectionist, and so was the honorable member for Grampians; but I was not, as I was supposed to be weak on the question of protection, though I leave it to the honorable member for Bourke to say who gave more votes for protection when the Tariff was under consideration, the honorable member for Grampians "or myself. There is some doubt as to who invented the phrase " new protection," but the honorable member for Maribyrnong claims that his party originated the ideas which it covers. If so, why did they take no steps to give effect to them, action being first taken in that direction by Senator Pearce?
Mr. Mauger.- The introduction of Wages Boardswas a much earlier application of new protection.

Mr. TUDOR.-Does the honorable member say that Wages Boards are the beginning and end of the new protection principle? Will he not say that new protection means the providing, by means of an Act of Parliament, that the employers in protected trades shall be compelled to pay fair wages to their workmen ? Does he say that in all protected industries fair wages are paid to-day under the Wages Boards?
Mr. Mauger.- It does not matter about the instrument, so long as we accomplish the object.
Mr. TUDOR.-Of course, I admit-
Mr. HumeCook. - Nothing has been more successful than the Wages Boards.

Mr. TUDOR.- The honorable member has never sat as a delegate on a Wages Board, or he would know that one delegate after another has been dismissed. As the honorable member for Maribyrnong is aware, every representative of the first Butchers Wages Board was dismissed for taking part.
Mr. Mauger.- That was an exceptional case.
Mr. HumeCook. - And we deplore it as much as any one.
Mr. TUDOR.- What guarantee is there that these men shall have any protection from their employers ?
Mr. HumeCook. - I say that so far, the Wages Boards are the most successful of any portion of the new protection.

Mr. TUDOR.-And I say that the Wages Boards do not touch the fringe of the new protection ; and after all, I speak with as much knowledge of the industrial conditions of the community as does the honorable member.
Mr. HumeCook. - But not more; I served my time to a trade, and that is, perhaps, what the Minister of Customs never did.

Mr. TUDOR.- I say that the first distinctive step, so far as this Parliament was concerned, in connexion with new protection, was taken by a member of the Labour Party ; that the second was taken by Senator Findley in regard to an Excise duty on spirits ; and that the third was taken by the present Prime Minister and the Minister of External Affairs in connexion with the Harvester Excise. I remember that when the honorable member for Maranoa asked either the honorable member for Ballarat, as Prime Minister, or the honorable member for Hume, as Minister of Customs, whether there would be introduced Excise provisions so far as the workers were concerned, the honorable member for Bourke exclaimed, "What, make our people here pay and allow the importers to go scot free? " Does the honorable memberfor Bourke not remember asking the question in opposition to the new protection ?
Mr. HumeCook. - I do not know anything about it.
Mr. TUDOR.- But the honorable member cannot deny my statement.
Mr. HumeCook. - I do not know anything at all about it.

Mr. TUDOR.- The honorable member's words can be found in Hansard. When the honorable member for Maribyrnong was speaking, about what I do not remember, just now, I interjected, " Like you did the Telegraph Bill." The honorable member for Ballarat will remember that a Bill was introduced making some alteration in the telegraph rates, and that at that time the use of telephones for betting purposes had been prohibited - a course to which I do not object. But when some of us expressed a desire to have a provision in the Bill then before the House, prohibiting the use of telegraphs for the same purpose, the Government dropped the Bill, and it has not been heard of from that day to this. I do not think that the honorable member for Maribyrnong was Postmaster-General at the time.
Mr. Mauger.- I know nothing of the matter, and never heard of it until now.
Mr. TUDOR.- I think it was when the honorable member for Eden-Monaro was Postmaster-General; but, at any rate, the honorable member for Maribyrnong was a member of the Ministry.
Mr. Mauger.- No; it was previous to my becoming a member of the Government.
Mr. TUDOR.- But the honorable member remembers the occurrence?
Mr. Mauger.- No; as I said before, this is the first time I have heard of it.

Mr. TUDOR.-At any rate, the Bill was dropped, and I remember the occasion very well, because I was one who voted for placing the telegraphs and telephones on the same basis in this connexion. I should not have spoken in this debate, but for the remarks made by the honorable member for Maribyrnong in regard to the method of selection of our party.I desire to place on record what I know of the method of the Labour Party and that of the party to which the honorable member belongs; and I contend that our method is infinitely more democratic, and results in a better expression of opinion by the people.

Mr. COON(Batman) [5.21].- As the Minister of Trade and Customs has mentioned my name, I desire to say that at no time did I sign any document to the effect that I would " stand down " at the last election if not selected.
Mr. Tudor.- I did not say the honorable member did.

Mr. COON.-The Minister said thatI signed a document to the effect that, in the event of my not being selected by the Ministry, I would " stand down " ; and I have to say that I was never asked to sign, and never did sign, any such document presented by the Ministry, or any other body or person. The honorable gentleman also said that, at one time, I stood as a candidate for the Collingwood City Council, as one not a Labour man, and was defeated; but that, on the second occasion, when I signed the platform of the Labour Party, I was returned. Let me tell the Minister that I never signed the platform.
Mr. Tudor.- Did the honorable member never sign the Labour pledge?
Mr. COON.- No; not as a Labour candidate for the Collingwood Council ; and, if he can produce any pledge that I have signed, I am prepared-
Mr. Tudor.- To resign ?

Mr. COON.- Yes, to resign straight away. I was never asked to sign the platform, and I never announced myself as a Labour candidate for the council. If the honorable member can produce any document showing that I was a Labour candidate, I shall take the step I have stated. What does the honorable gentleman desire to infer? The very gentleman, Mr. Edward Lewis, who waited on the Government in regard to my selection, is now a representative at the Trades Hall. He attended as a delegate at the conference, and came to the Minister asking for support, heading the deputation ; and he is the president of the league. Is that the gentleman who gave the Minister the information that I was asked to sign the platform?
Mr. Tudor.- No ; it is another gentleman.
Mr. J.H. Catts. - How does the honorable member for Batman like his present company ?
Mr. COON.- I am in the right company, behind the gentleman I was sent here to support. Ought I to be on the other side ?
Mr. Thomas.- No.

Mr. COON.- The honorable member says " No," and I shall try to prove that there is good reason for my not being there. There is a party in power to-day without any fiscal policy. The present Prime Minister, in October last, boasted that his party was the only party that came into the House without a fiscal belief.
Mr. J.H. Catts. - We are, every man of us. pledged to new protection.

Mr. COON.-I have stated what the Prime Minister said in October. When I asked the Prime Ministerin this House, to declare the policy of the Government on the fiscal question, he said he would do so at the proper time. The proper time was at Gympie; but what he said there was that, rightly or wrongly, the Federal Parliament had declared for protection, and that, so far as his Ministry were concerned, they had not declared for protection at all. Why should I sit behind a Ministry composed of fiscal atheists? I was not sent here far that purpose.
Mr. Thomas.- No one that I know of is complaining that the honorable member does not sit behind the Ministry.

Mr. COON.- The honorable member for Barrier, when the proposed duties on mining machinery were before us, made a strong plea for the poor shareholders in the Broken Hill mines, declaring that if they were imposed they would not be able to pay their calls.
Mr. Thomas.- And the honorable member is now sitting behind the honorable member for Kooyong, Mr. Knox.

Mr. COON.-No, I am sitting behind the honorable member for Ballarat, whom the honorable member for Darwin has described as the natural PrimeMinister of Australia. I am asked to support a Ministry, the members of which might do as they pleased with the Tariff, as evidenced by the fact that the honorable member for Cook took twenty-four hours to make up his mind whether he should vote for a certain duty, and finally voted for its reduction. The Attorney-General during this debate has made an attack upon the present leader of the Opposition. Only a few weeks ago I heard the honorable member deliver at Randwick a speech, in which he declared that between the Deakin party and his own there was everything in common. To-day we are told that they have nothing in common, and, according to the honorable member, there is nothing too bad to be said of the leader of the Opposition. Why this sudden change? Speaking at Randwick the Attorney-General declared that the honorable member for Ballarat and his party would not go back on the Labour Ministry ; but on the very night that he made that statement a member of the Deakin party had thirteen Labour candidates nominated in opposition to him. Is it reasonable to expect an honorable member in such circumstances to stand by the party? I am expected to be loyal to the present Government, but I am loyal to my constituents, and to them alone. I am here to assist in passing legislation that I believe will be in the best interests of the people. Is it reasonable that I should be asked to support a Ministry composed of free-traders such as the Attorney -General, the Minister of Home Affairs, the PostmasterGeneral, the Minister of Defence, and also the Minister of External Affairs? Honorable members may smile when I refer in this way to the Minister of External Affairs, but I venture to say that an examination of the records will show that when the Tariff was before us he voted for free-trade more often than he voted for protection. Did not the honorary Minister charge his own party with having changed a protectionist Tariff, as introduced by the Deakin Ministry, into a revenue Tariff? That being so, what does he now propose to do? The PrimeMinister has said nothing as to the intentions of the Government regarding the fiscal question. He has not fulfilled his promise to make a statement in that regard, and I should like him now to say whether the Ministry have decided to adopt a protectionist or a freetrade policy. I am here to support the policy of protection.
Mr. Webster.- The honorable member will have a great chance over there.

Mr. COON.-I think that I shall have a far better chance of doing so behind a protectionist leader thanI should have if I sat behind a fiscal atheist. That being so, I make no apology for the vote I gave yesterday. It was in accordance with my pledges, and I do not doubt that the future of Australia will be perfectly safe if intrusted to the honorable member who I believe in the very near future will occupy the position of Prime Minister.

Sir WILLIAMLYNE (Hume) [5.31].- I wish to make a personal explanation. The right honorable member for Swan a few minutes ago introduced the name of the Under-Secretary to the Treasury, in his effort to refute an assertion I had made regarding the burning of some copies of a Banking Bill. I have visited the Treasury and have seen the Under-Secretary, who says that he is not certain whether the right honorable member on the occasion referred to gave an instruction that the documents should be " burnt," but that an instruction was certainly given to suppress them. He remembers that I directed that they should not be destroyed, but that one or two copies should be sent to me. There is a memorandum on the file that one copy, if not two, should be forwarded to me. The Under-Secretary to the Treasury suggested to me, he says, that the documents should not be destroyed, and he put them together and deposited them in the strong room, where they have since remained. He supports my statement, in so far as he says thatthe documents were to be suppressed. I said that I was present when I heard the instruction given that they should be burnt, but the Under-Secretary is not prepared to say whether the word "burnt" was actually used, although he knows that they were to be suppressed.

Mr. MATHEWS(Melbourne Ports) [5.33]. - So much has been said regarding the taking of a pledge that one would almost think it a crime to take one. Is there any Rechabite who so regards the taking of the pledge of his order? I am proud of the pledge I have taken, and, although I regret to have to make any personal references, I wish to ask the honorable member for Batman if it is not a fact that during his membership of the Labour Party he signed a pledge. The honorable member does not reply, and I do not wish to press him for an answer. The honorable member for Maribyrnong said that his objection to our system of selection is that a candidate has to sign a pledge that if he is not selected he will not oppose the selected candidate.

Mr. Mauger.- My objection is that a man who has held office as a Minister - who has been elected by thousands of people - must, before he goes back to the people, run the gauntlet of a clique, a machine, or a small body of men.
Mr. MATHEWS.-I would ask the honorable member to point to one member of the Labour Party who has lost his seat at the selection of candidates.
Mr. Mauger.- Yes; I could give the honorable member the name privately.

Mr. MATHEWS.-I have been in the Labour movement for years, and have never known a man yet who held a seat and lost it at the selection of candidates. I know of one man who held two-fifths of a seat, but lost it to another man who represented portion of another electorate.
Mr. HumeCook. - I could give the honorable member more than one instance in Victoria.

Mr. MATHEWS.- It would be news to me. Many honorable members have made a lot out of the statement that the great protectionist movement and the Tariff are in danger, but I believe there are enough protectionists in the House to insure the safety of protection, and that we have enough protectionists even to increase the Tariffwhen we get an opportunity. There are also men who came into the House as free-traders, but who have admitted publicly and privately that the fiscal issue is dead, and that protection is the accepted and established policy of Australia. The Argus newspaper itself has admitted it, so that I have no fear on that score, whatever Ministry is formed. But what I do fear from what is taking place now is that the democracy of Australia will be in danger when the fusion party come over from the other side to take the Treasury bench. I ask honorable members to recall the splendid leading article that appeared in the Age of the 15th of this month, warning the honorable member for Ballarat that the course he was pursuing was a treacherous course to the democracy, and that he would not be able to perpetrate what he was endeavouring to do, because such sturdy democrats as the honorable member for Maribyrnong, the honorable member for Bourke, the honorable member for Gippsland, the honorable member for

Batman, the honorable member for Hume, the honorable member for Laanecoorie, and the honorable member for Riverina, would prevent him from selling the democracy to the crusted Conservatives in the corner.
Mr.Deakin. - That was when I proposed to stand out.

Mr. MATHEWS-A short fortnight ago, the Age uttered that warning, and more than a warning, to the honorable member for Ballarat, yet in the Age of yesterday we saw the names of the new Liberal Cabinet, and the new Liberal Party. In that new party, arrayed beside the honorable member for Ballarat, and the honorable member for Maribyrnong, were the honorable members for Parramatta, Bendigo - a great democrat - and Fawkner - a gentleman who makes no pretence of democracy, and who is chairman of the most conservative .organization in Australia, the Employers' Federation. I ask the democrats of Australia, much as they admire the honorable member for Fawkner, as an individual, whether they expect one atom of democratic feeling or action from him. I would ask the 'members of the late Deakin party, as they were known then, particularly the honorable members for Maribyrnong, Bourke, Batman, and Laanecoorie, whether they -dare go before their constituents, and say that they are one and all united with the honorable member for Flinders. Those four honorable members will look well in the eyes of the democrats of their constituencies sitting cheek by jowl with the honorable members for Flinders, Grampians, Corangamite, Echuca, Bendigo, Kooyong, Fawkner, and Indi - all grand democrats in the new Liberal Party. I have hundreds of times stated on the platform that there was no real, difference - and I have been taken to task for it by friends of honorable members sitting opposite^ - between the honorable members for Maribyrnong and Bourke, for instance, and the honorable member for Flinders, because, while they were not pledged to support democratic legislation, the time would come when they would get away from it. They have proved the truth of our assertion. I have heard of missionaries going to the Solomon- Islands to be eaten, or to China to be killed, and I suppose those honorable members have gone as missionaries into the ranks of the Conservatives with a strong determination to convert those gentlemen to democracy. T can say with perfect truth that the Opposition corner and the Opposition itself, ^before the remnant of the Deakin party joined it, did not contain one member with a shred of democracy about him. In spite of all that the sturdy democrats enumerated by the Age, on the 15th inst, can do, and in spite of the smiling face that they put upon the position which they are now occupying, they know well that they are no more at home over there than I. would be. The present situation has been brought about because the Labour organization has openly admitted that it will nominate pledged Labour men against those honorable members. But this is not the first time that that has been done. It was done at the last election. The fight was "fought, and some won, and some lost. But when the House met, there was no embittered feeling on the part of Labour members towards the members of the Deakin party. Although we had been engaged in strife at the .elections, almost immediately after we met here we got into one line of action. Strongly as the honorable members who have crossed the floor have fought the Labour movement iri the past, and succeeded, they never yet: made such a mistake, and never played so1 much into our hands as they have now done by going over to the other side. As surely as we stand here to-day, their action will redound to the benefit off the Labour movement. I believe that the influence of the Opposition Corner Party will be detrimental tothe genuine democrats who are supportingthe honorable member for Ballarat. Their influence will more than counterbalancethat of the democratic members in formulating the policy of the incoming Government. No doubt the members of theCorner Party believe that their policywould be best for the country. I believefirmly that they think that it is to the interest of Australia that a -few should be better off than the many. It is inevitablethat the influence of those honorable members should affect the sincere democratswho sit opposite. Personally, I do not consider that our party has anything tocomplain of in the present situation. Whenit was announced that our party could no longer support the Government of the hon.orable member for Ballarat last year, I never in my most sanguine momentsdreamt that we should occupy the Government benches. I thought that . we should' be in direct Opposition. I knew that wewere a minority, and considered that the-

Opposition side was our true place in this House. But events shaped themselves differently. Why? Because those who are supporting the honorable member for Ballarat to-day did not support him in his hour of need. I have heard some of them say a hundred times that the only objection they had to the Deakin Government was that it was kept in power by the Labour Party. They say now that they knew all along that they could get good legislation from the Deakin Party, but that that legislation was permitted to be moulded to too great an extent by the Labour Party. Yet when we announced to the late Government thatwe could no longer support them the then Opposition made no move to support the Deakin Government. When a division took place, a few moved in their seats, but the honorable member for Ballarat told them to stay where they were. That was the time when they should have crossed the floor. But they did not, because they felt that there were men occupying seats in that Cabinet which they themselves ought to have, and they said - " We will turn the Government out first and there will be a reconstruction afterwards." That is what is taking place now. We shall attain out true position in the House as a direct Opposition. Being, as we are, a compact body of men, who attend to their legislative work - do not let honorable members forget that - the incoming Government will have such an anxious time in keeping a House that if we do not secure a dissolution now, as I think we ought to do, the dissolution will undoubtedly come in a very short time. I believe that when we come back there will be just as many parties in the House as there are now. Thatis only natural. The people themselves are divided on political issues, and this Parliament ought to be a true reflex of what the people think. The party supporting the honorable member for Ballarat will come back with just as many sections in it as there are to-day. There is only one party in which there are no sections, and that is the Labour Party. The Opposition Corner Party must have contained about a dozen sections, because they could never select a leader. There will always be different parties in a country where there are many shades of political thought. The honorable member for Ballarat may think that he has behind him a party of cohesion, but I have my doubts as to whether he is of that opinion, and am satisfied that he will find that he has such a restive team in hand that his legislation cannot be democratic. His supporters will take good care of that. Does he suppose that the honorable members for Fawkner, Flinders, Corangamite, and Echuca want democratic legislation, or legislation beneficial to the workers ? If he does not suppose that, he should not have agreed to a coalition, and if he does suppose it it is like expecting water to flow uphill. The interestsof these men are against advanced legislation. It is said that "evil communications corrupt good manners." I must express the hope that such will not be the case with the democrats who support the honorable member for Ballarat.
Mr.Mauger. - No danger.

Mr. MATHEWS.-Our party has nothing to growl at in what has happened. But, personally, I regret to say that in the future I can never look upon the honorable member for Ballarat in the same light as I have done in the past. He will admit that I always have meted out to him as much assistance as I could render, and have repeatedly expressed my admiration for him personally.I am sorry to say - although he may not care - that in future I shall be unable to extend that consideration to him that I have hitherto given. When I heard the honorable member for Ballarat hurl defiance at honorable members in the opposite corner, when they were goading and jeering at him, I felt that he would always be found adopting that attitude towards those honorable members. When I heard him tell the members of the Corner Party to sit where they were, and that he did not want their support, I felt that he would look for democratic support.
Mr.Hedges. - This is all in the honorable member's imagination. He is the only man who heard it.
Mr.Bamford. - Many heard it.

Mr. MATHEWS.- There are none so deaf as the willing deaf. However, a change has come about, and we must accept things as they are. If we get any good legislation from the multum in parvo on the opposite side, I shall be very pleased.
